results.title: TV: the anonymous teacher
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey C. Weber, Episcopal Church, Media Action Research Center and United Methodist Communications
results.brief_description: Television is more than entertainment, it always “teaches” children and adults. Experts are interviewed to try and find out the effect of television on children. Broadcasters seem to see TV purely as a sales agent, and children grow up to grade three, implicitly believing all the advertisements as well as everything else they see. Deals with the impact of violence, racial and sexual stereotyping, commercials, and postitive and negative values in programming. Offers some suggestions for television programs as well as suggesting action for change. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: West wind: the story of Tom Thomson
results.creator_credit: Graham McInnes and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Tom Thomson’s jack pine, painted against a background of lake and sky, has come to symbolize the Canadian North. This film outlines the story of Tom Thomson’s brief life (1877-1917) and career, which began in Toronto, where he worked as a commercial artist. Weekend sketching trips in the country turned into longer journeys farther north, and Thomson finally moved to Algonquin Park, in northern Ontario. When he wasn’t painting and canoeing, he was a park guide. We watch wonderful photography of his favourite landscapes, interspersed with images of the paintings they inspired. Thomson spent less than four years as an artist and was barely 40 when a canoe accident ended his life. Fellow artists Lawren Harris, A.Y. Jackson and Arthur Lismer pay tribute to this genius, who, in Jackson’s words, “contributed more to Canadian painting than any other artist.”
results.title_for_label: West wind: the story of Tom Thomson

results.title: Digital Storytelling Express workshop
results.brief_description: Four stories as created by members of the general public for Digital Storytelling’s DST Express workshop. These stories, all of less than two minutes, cover life changing events, major lessons and inspirational family members.

results.title: To track a shadow
results.creator_credit: George Kaczender, William Canning and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: There is sometimes danger and excitement, but always a patient follow-up of clues when the R.C.M.P. hunt a killer. This film re-enacts a case from the files of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to show what is involved in modern crime detection. Some clues turn up in the laboratory; the trail of evidence leads from a lonely Alberta road to a British Columbia lumber camp and a final shootout with the murderer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Kaczender, William Canning and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: To the edge of the universe [short version]
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree, Dennis Sawyer, Douglas Cameron and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An account of the construction, in Algonquin Park, Ontario, of a radiotelescope designed by Canada’s National Research Council. Working simultaneously with the telescope of the Dominion Radio Astrophysical Observatory at Penticton, British Columbia, it was used to measure the first arc of a quasar (quasi-stellar radio source) at the outermost fringe of our universe. The success of this probe opened up new possibilities of astronomical enquiry.

results.title: The World changes: Japan's new family patterns
results.creator_credit: Hugh Gage and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description: A day in the life of a typical Japanese family living in Kyoto illustrates the changes which have occured in social institutions since World War II. The heritage of ancient traditions is still apparent but post-war life provides new opportunities for the children. Shows schooling, marketing and preparation of the evening meal.

results.title: The World changes: Japan's geography - human and economic
results.creator_credit: Hugh Gage and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description: Outlines the geographical features of the four mountainous islands of Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu, their climate and population density. Also covers the impact of modernisation, the growth of the cities, particularly Tokyo, the way of life in the country, research and technology, the basis of the economy and the skill and industry of the people.

results.title: The World changes: Japan's food from land and sea
results.creator_credit: Hugh Gage and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description: Illustrates how Japan’s mountainous land is made productive through terracing, contour farming, chemical fertilizers, crop rotation and research. Also looks at the fishing industry and efficient vegetable handling and marketing practices.
